files.fulltext:
MERDE

THE

4BV

1030

Copy 1 ORIGIN AND HISTORY

OF THE

“Church of Christ I si Middleman,

WITH THE

COVENANT, CONFESSION OF FAITH, & c.,

AND LIST OF MEMBEBS.

o '

;v -

SALEM:

PRINTED AT THE REGISTER PRESS.

1850.

^-3 V

/030

ORIGIN AND HISTORY

OF THE

“Church of Christ in Middleton.”

This Church was formed the 22d of October, 1729. The names of those who formed it may be seen on the last pages of this Manual. The following is the Covenant they agreed upon and assented to :—

COVENANT.

We, whose names are hereunto subscribed, lamenting our great unfitness for such an awful and solemn approach to God, and bewailing all the miscarriages committed by us either in the dark days of unregeneracy or since we have been brought unto an acquaintance with God in the communion of his churches which we heretofore have been related to, yet apprehending ourselves called by the Most High to embody ourselves into a distinct society, with a sacred covenant, to worship the Lord Jesus Christ, and to edify one another ac¬ cording to the rules of his holy word, being persuaded in matters of faith according to the Confession owned and con¬ sented to by the Churches assembled at Boston, in New England, which for substance we now own and confess.

We do, in some measure of sincerity, this day give up ourselves to God in Christ, to be for him and not another, at the same time renouncing all the vanities and idols of this present world. We do likewise give up ourselves and our

4

offi-pring unto the Lord Jehovah, the one true and living God in three persons. Father, Son and Holy Ghost, as our only sanctifier and comforter as to our best good and last end,^ promising by divine help to live unto and upon this one God in three persons, hoping at length to dwell with Him forever. Also, we do likewise give up ourselves one to another in the Lord, engaging with Divine aid, as a church of God, to sub¬ mit to the order and discipline and government of Christ in * this his church, and the ministerial teaching, guidance and oversight of the Elder thereof, as to such as watch for our souls, and also to a mutual and brotherly watchfulness ac¬ cording to the gospel rules, so long as we shall continue in this relation one to the other. And we promise also to walk with all regular and due communion with other churches of our Lord Jesus Christ, and call for their help and counsel as need may require; and we will endeavor to support and preserve the pure gospel and institutions of our Lord and Re¬ deemer so far as he shall graciously reveal to us his mind and will concerning them.

We resolve uprightly to study what is our duty, and to make it our grief and reckon it our shame, whereinsoever we find we come short of it; and for pardon thereof we hum¬ bly betake ourselves to the blood of the everlasting covenant.

And that we may keep this covenant, in all the branches of it, inviolably forever, being deeply sensible of our own in¬ sufficiency therefor, we beg the grace and assistance of our Mediator may be sufficient for us. Beseeching Him that, while we are working out our own salvation w ith fear and trembling, He would graciously work in us both to will and to do; and that He, being the great Shepherd of our souls, would lead us in paths of righteousness for his own name’s sake, and at length receive us all into the inheritance of the saints in light. Amen.

The Rev. Mr. Peters, the first Pu9tor of this Church, was settled Nov. 13, 1729, and remained with us 27 years. He was a devoted, successful minister, and the church evi¬ dently prospered under his ministry. He died Oct. 6, 1756, aged 56. He rests with us, and a tombstone still marks the place of his burial.

In March 1759, thirty years after this church was formed, and three months after the ordination of their second Pastor, the Rev. Elias Smith, the church met and drew up a confession of faith, one which bears testimony that they were an Evangelical growing church of Christ. Their Confession of Faith was the following :—

CONFESSION OF FAITH.

1. You seriously and solemnly profess to believe in one Eternal Almighty God, the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost, who created the world by His power, and governs it by His providence, and is the Redeemer of this fallen world by His Son Jesus Christ.

2. You believe the Holy Scriptures of the Old and New Testament to be the word of God, and adhere to them as the only perfect rule of faith and practice.

3. You believe that our first parents fell from the state of integrity, honor and happiness in which God at first created them, by their transgression in eating the forbidden fruit, and thereby involved themselves and their posterity in a state of sin and death.

4. You believe that God, in compassion to the sinful per¬ ishing state of mankind, foreordained and in the fulness of time sent IIis only begotten Sou to be the Saviour of this world.

5. And that Jesus Christ, in compliance w : th his Father’s will, took upon him the nature of man, and therein humbled himself in his obedience unto death for our redemption.

6

6. That he rose again the third day, and ascended into heaven as our victorious Redeemer, and sitteth at the right hand of God, making intercession for us, and having power; given him over all things in heaven and on earth.

7. That he sustains and executes the three-fold office of Prophet, Priest, and King, in his church.

8. That in the exercise of this office as Redeemer, and of this fulness of power committed to him, he has published th^ J Gospel covenant, requiring faith and repentance of sinful men, in order to pardon and salvation.

9. You believe tbe Holy Spirit is given through the merits and intercession of Christ, to make application of his pur¬ chased redemption to men’s souls, and that his gracious in¬ fluences are necessary to a life of faith and obedience.

10. You believe that Christ has instituted a Gospel Min¬ istry, and ihe two Sacraments of Baptism and the Lord’s Supper, to be observed in his church till his second coming.

11. You believe in another life after this; and that Christ will come again and raise the dead, and judge the world, and that we must all appear before his judgment seat.

12. That at the last day the wicked shall be adjudged to everlasting punishment, and the righteous to life eternal.— Amen.

The Rev. Mr. Smith was settled on the 10th of January 1759, and remained 33 years with this people. The Con¬ fession of Faith drawn up three months after his settlement, and other votes of the church during his ministry, make it evident that he was a faithful evangelical minister, and that the church prospered under his watch and care. lie died October 17, 1791, aged 61 years. He too rests with us, and a tombstone marks the place of his burial.

i

The next Minister was the Rev. Solomon Adams. He was ordained and settled October 23d, 1793, and remained with this people 20 years. lie died Sept. 4, 1813, aged 52 . Fie, and his predecessor in the ministry, sleep in the same tomb.

The Rev. Ebenezer Hubbard was the next Pastor. Pe was ordained and settled November 27, 1816. He re¬ mained with this people twelve years, and vvas dismissed April 30, 1828.

During the next three years, the church, which seems to have backslidden under the pastorships of Mr. Adams and Mr. Hubbard, revived, and in the latter part of the year 1831, gave the Rev. Forrest Jefferds a call to settle with them; but the parish, desiring unevangelical preaching part of the time, refused to concur with them. Accordingly the church, with the loss of only two male and one or two female members, withdrew, leaving behind the meeting-house, com¬ munion furniture, church fund, & c.*

*These two male and one or two female members referred to as remaining behind, are deceased; and as none were ever added to their number, that branch of the “Church of Christ in Middleton’ ’ is dead.

The Rev. Mr. Jefferds was settled May 2d, 1832; he was a faithful and successful laborer. He remained twelve years with this people, and was dismissed May 15, 1844.

The Rev. Thurston Searle was the next Minister. He was ordained and settled May 8, 1845, and was dis¬ missed Dec. 23, 1846.

The present Pastor, Rev. J. Augustine Hood, was ordained and settled January 2, 1850.

8

R U L E S

OF “THE CHURCH OF CHRIST IN MIDDLETON.”

Article 1 There shall be a business meeting of this church on the second Wednesday of January annually, af which time shall be chosen a Treasurer, Clerk and Standing Committee. At this meeting the Treasurer’s account shall be presented to the church.

Art. 2. The Standing Committee shall consist of the. Pastor, the Deacons, and two other brethren. It shall be the duty of this Committee to examine all applicants for ad¬ mission to this church relative to their Christian experience.

Art. 3. Candidates for admission on profession shall also be examined by the church, and if approved, shall stand publicly propounded at least one week, and assent to our cov¬ enant in presence of the congregation, before admission to full communion.

Art. 4. This church deem immoral conduct, wilful breach of covenant vows, neglect of acknowledged religious duties, and avowed disbelief of the articles of faith to which the members have assented, as offences subject to the cen¬ sure of the church.

Art. 5. The censures of the church are private reproof, public admonition, suspension from church privileges, and excommunication, according to the aggravation of the of¬ fence.

Art. 6. In ordinary cases, if a member convicted on any article of charge do not give satisfactory evidence of re¬ pentance, the church, through one or more of its officers, shall give him a written admonition; if that fail to bring him to repentance, shall give him another; and if both be ineffec- tual, he shall be cut off from the church.

Art. 7. As this church regard it a binding and sacred duty for Christian parents to consecrate their children to God in baptism, there ought to be no unnecessary delay in the performance of this duty.

9

FORM OF ABMISSlOlf TO MEMBER ' SHIR IN THE

. * ( CHURCH OF CHRIST IN MIDDLETON.”

You have presented yourselves in this public manner* before God, to dedicate yourselves to Ilis service, and to unite with His visible people.

You are about to profess supreme love to God, sincere contrition for all your sins, and faith unfeigned in the Lord Jesus Christ.

Relying on the strength of Divine grace, yoU are about to ■enter into a solemn covenant to receive the Father, Son and Holy Ghost as they are offered in the gospeL, and to walk ill nil the commandments and ordinances of the Lord blameless.

We trust you have well considered the nature of these pro¬ fessions and engagements. The transaction is solemn. God tind holy angels are witnesses. Your vows will be recorded in heaven. Yet* be not overwhelmed with these reflections. Yoti come at the bidding of Christ to confess him before men* and yoU may Confidently trust in him for strength to perform your vows, and hereafter to confess you before his Father and the holy angels. You will now consent to the following CONFESSION OF FAITH.

L You believe there is one only living and trite God, the Father, the Son, and the ftoly Ghost, and that these three are one God, the same in substance, equal in power and glory.

2. You believe that the Scriptures of the Old and New Testament were given by inspiration of God, and are the only infallible rule of faith and practice.

3. You believe that by nature all mankind are entirely destitute of holiness, possessing the carnal mind which is en¬ mity against God.

4. You believe that in the iufiuite mercy of God, a way

10

of salvation has been provided through the mediation and death of our Lord Jesus Christ.

5. You believe that repentance for sin, and faith in the Lord Jesus Christ, are the indispensable requisites for salva¬ tion.

6. You believe that regeneration is a spiritual change, ef¬ fected by the special agency of the Holy Spirit, and that this change is absolutely necessary to salvation.

7. You believe that man is an active, free moral agent; and that his free agency or activity is not suspended when the Holy Spirit exercises in him His offices of conviction, re¬ generation and sanctification.

8. You believe that all who are born of the Spirit, are kept by Him through faith unto salvation.

9. You believe that God has established a church in the world; that its special ordinances are two, Baptism and the Lord’s Supper; that Baptism is to be administered to believ¬ ers and their seed; and that the Lord’s Supper is to be par¬ taken of only by those who have professed their Saviour be¬ fore men.

10. You believe that at the end of the world there will be a general resurrection and a final judgment; that Christ will sit as judge; that the wicked shall be adjudged to never- ending punishment, and the righteous to life eternal. You will now enter into solemn covenant with God and this church.

COVENANT.

Being deeply sensible of your dependence upon God, your own unworthiness, and your obligation to love and obey Him; and humbly trusting that you have experienced c ‘the washing of regeneration and the renewing of the Holy Ghost,” you do now in the presence of God and these witnesses, declare the Lord Jehovah, Father, Son and Holy Ghost, to be your God, the supreme object of your affections, and your chosen portion forever.

11

You do cordially receive the Lord Jesus Christ in all his offices, as your Prophet, Priest and King, as your only Sa¬ viour, and final Judge.

You receive the Holy Ghost as your sanctifier, comforter and guide; and cheerfully consecrate yourself to the sacred Three in One, in the everlasting covenant of grace.

You promise to give diligent attention to the word and or¬ dinances of God, to family worship, secret prayer, and to the observance of the Lord’s day.

You engage to watch over your own heart and life, and to guard against whatever may have a tendency to bring dis¬ honor on the Christian profession.

You likewise covenant with this church, that you will sub¬ mit to its order and discipline; that you will seek its peace and welfare; that you will walk with its members in Chris¬ tian love, faithfulness and meekness. Thus you covenant, promise, and engage.

[ The ordinance of Baptism , if not previously received , will here be administered .]

I, as ministering to you in holy things, do now, in the pres¬ ence of God and these witnesses, and in the name of this church, declare you to be a member of this Church, entitled to its ordinances and privileges, its communion and fellow¬ ship, its watch and care.

[ The Church will rise.]

And now do we, the members of this church, in conse¬ quence of these your professions and promises, affectionately receive you to our communion. We welcome you to a fel¬ lowship with us in the blessings of the gospel, engaging on our part to love you as Christians, to watch over you, to pray for you, to seek your edification so long as you shall continue among us.

[The Church will here be seated.]

12

And now, beloved in the Lord, let it be impressed on your minds that you have entered into solemn relations, which you can never renounce, and from which you can never be re¬ leased. Hereafter the eyes of the world will be upon you. As you conduct yourself, so will religion be honored or dis¬ graced. If you walk worthy of your profession, you will be a credit and comfort to us; but if it be otherwise, it will be an occasion of grief and reproach. But, beloved ' , we are per-* suaded better things of you, and things which accompany salvatioa, although we thus speak. We charge you, forget not this day. Be faithful unto death; for, if found faithful, it will not be long before you are admitted into that world, where no longer through the medium of ordinances, but with open face, you shall behold the glory of the Lord, and, changed into the same image, from glory to glory, shall dwell forever in his presence.

May the Lord guide and preserve you through this transi¬ tory life, and at last receive you and us to that blessed world where our love and joy shall be forever perfect. Amen.

LIST OF DEACONS.

1729 John Berry. 1794 Benjamin Peabody.

1729 Samuel Symonds, 1794 John Nichols.
